ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

GLORIFICATION OF TERRORISM

(Legislation)

     1.  Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs whether the Government will introduce legislation making the glorification of terrorism a crime.

     The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs):  Mr Speaker, Sir, there are already existing laws to deal with those who incite violence by glorifying violence. For instance, section 153 of the Penal Code makes it an offence for any person to provoke rioting. The Sedition Act makes it an offence to promote feelings of ill-will and hostility between different races or classes of the population of Singapore, and section 8(1)(a) of the Internal Security Act provides for detention in order to prevent a person from acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of Singapore or to the maintenance of public order. These laws have proven adequate over the years to deal not only with those who encourage terrorism but also any others who threaten our racial and religious harmony through their inflammatory actions or words.

 

Column: 308

     In any case, MHA will continue to monitor legal developments in other countries addressing the evolving threat of terrorism, and make appropriate amendments to our laws if the need arises.

 

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah):  Sir, would the Minister agree that since the Singapore law is primarily based on the common law and since the UK Parliament has found it necessary to legislate that glorification of terrorism is a crime, would he agree that there might be a gap in our laws that our current law would not cover where the current UK law would now cover?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee:  Even though Singapore laws are based on the common law, in many areas we have evolved our own ways, including our laws on terrorism and also our Penal Code is based on the Indian Penal Code because England has no written Penal Code.  Also, in terms of what happened in England, particularly post-July 7th, I think they found it necessary to plug the gap.  But I want to assure the Member that we have found no gap so far and, of course, we will continue to monitor if the need arises.  If necessary, we will plug any gap because we will leave no stone unturned to ensure that we have adequate laws to take care of this scourge.

     Mr Speaker:  Dr Wang, last question.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen:  Thank you, Sir.  The Minister indicated that he would monitor and would plug the hole when the need arises.  Would he want to follow the UK example that they would only pass such a law after a terrorist attack in the tube? If a similar event happens in Singapore, would it be a bit too late to plug the gap?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee:  Sir, from our experience, the main thrust of my answer is that we have detected no gap. 

Column: 309

That is the main point.  We have adequate laws to deal with these acts that Dr Wang has mentioned.

COMPETITION COMMISSION OF SINGAPORE

(Complaints filed)

     2.  Prof. Ivan Png Paak Liang asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) how many complaints have been filed with the Competition Commission of Singapore; (b) whether the complainants were consumers, other businesses, suppliers, or Government agencies; and (c) what is the current disposition of the complaints.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Lim Hng Kiang):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the Competition Commission of Singapore has received two complaints since 1st January 2006, when the enforcement provisions of the Competition Act came into force. The complaints were filed by consumers and members of the public.

 

     The Competition Commission is currently looking into these complaints, establishing the facts of the case, the nature and details of the alleged agreement or conduct and its effect on competition. The Commission is unable to reveal more information as all case information must necessarily be kept confidential during this stage when it is still conducting its examination. 

     Prof. Ivan Png Paak Liang (Nominated Member):  I have two supplementary questions for the hon. Minister.  Sir, recently the Coffeeshop Association has announced a 10-cent rise in the price of coffee nationwide.  This, to me, strikes as an example of price fixing.  Will the hon. Minister say whether the Competition Commission will be investigating this case?  Before the Competition Act came into force this year, last December, the School Bus Operators Association raised

Column: 310

fares across the board and affected many school children across all schools.  May I ask the hon. Minister if the School Bus Owners Association were to do so again this year, would the Competition Commission investigate them for price fixing? 

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang:  Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member raised two questions, but I will take them in a general context.  In general, we have trade associations and business associations set up to help its members.  Sometimes, they venture into statements which talk about prices of their services.  This is a generic issue and we will be looking at this whole issue of associations giving guidelines to their members on prices of their services.

SCHOOL BUS FARES

     3.  Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim asked the Minister for Transport whether his Ministry will request the Singapore School Transport Association to periodically and extensively publish the detailed breakdowns of the components that constitute the monthly school bus fares charged by the school bus companies under this Association so as to enhance transparency in the frequent requests for fare adjustments.

 

     4.  Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim asked the Minister for Transport whether his Ministry has plans to stipulate that the Singapore School Transport Association submits future school bus fare increases to the Public Transport Council for approval, similar to the requests for transport fare increase made by the public transport providers. 

 

     The Minister for Transport (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong):  Mr Speaker, as Question Nos. 3 and 4 are addressing the same issue, may I take them together?

     Mr Speaker:  Yes, please.

Column: 311

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:  Thank you. Sir, Prof. Ong asked for school bus fares to be regulated by PTC. School bus fares, unlike public transport fares, do not follow a common fare structure because school bus services are contractual in nature and are based on the mutual agreement between the bus operators and the parents of school children.  The school bus services do not operate along fixed routes. Also, the monthly school bus fare could vary significantly depending on factors such as distances travelled, pick-up locations, number of children ferried per trip from that location, and any other arrangements agreed between the bus operator and the school or parent.  As such, school buses do not come under the purview of the Public Transport Council (PTC) Act, which provides for the regulation of scheduled bus services.

 

     While we do not regulate their fares, on its part, LTA has put in place measures to help school bus operators keep their operating costs low. For example, operators owning registered CB plate school buses are exempted from paying the Quota Premium when they replace their older buses, or the Prevailing Quota Premium. 

 

     LTA has also introduced competition in the school bus service sector, by allowing owners of private hire and excursion buses to also provide school transport services. As these buses are not exempted from the Vehicle Quota System, the owners are given a 50% road tax rebate on such buses to partially offset the cost of the COE.

 

     With regard to Prof. Ong's request for more transparency in the fare adjustments, she will be pleased to know that the Singapore School Transport Association (SSTA) has taken some steps in this direction.

 

     In its press conference on 27th December last year to announce the fare

Column: 312

increases for school bus services, SSTA explained why the fare increase was necessary and how the recommended fare range was derived.  SSTA also stated that its recommendations were based on a commissioned study which identified the various cost elements of school bus operations.

 

     Such efforts by the SSTA to be more transparent and accountable to the public are commendable and should be encouraged. Prof. Ong may wish to contact SSTA directly for the study report if she would like to understand the fare increase better.

     Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim (Nominated Member):  Sir, my first question is: is the Ministry satisfied with the reasons given by the bus operator for collecting bus fares during the holiday months of the school?  Because, apparently, many of these bus operators use their buses for other purposes to earn extra income during the holidays, for example, ferrying tourists and other excursion trips.  So in a way, they are actually making profits. Is the Ministry satisfied that they should collect bus fares from the parents, especially from the low-income parents, when $30 or $40 per month is a lot of money to a low-income family?

 

     My second question is, since they do not come under the purview of PTC and the Ministry, is the Ministry and PTC aware that the consumers, that is, the parents, are being exploited by these bus companies?  For example, class starts at 1.00 o'clock, the bus operator will insist to come and pick up the kids at 11.15am when the kids barely even have time to have their lunch at home.  In a way to maximise their profits, they are exploiting the consumers.  So would the Ministry do something on this?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:  Sir, on her two questions, whether we are satisfied that the school buses are collecting fares

Column: 313

during the school holidays, as I mentioned just now, the school bus service is a contractual service between the parents and the service provider.  It is therefore up to them to work out the terms and to abide by the terms.  If the parents do not agree with the terms, I am sure they can find other alternatives.  Similarly, the second question on whether the consumers are exploited because the school buses pick up the students so early, I am sure the bus operators have got good reasons.  Again, if the parents do not agree, they can always look for another school bus service or find other alternative means of transport.  And the public transport system is right there for them to make full use of.

     Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim:  Sir, I was a student myself in primary and secondary schools.  I was taking the school bus then and my parents had to pay, although we were very poor.

    Mr Speaker:  No speeches, Prof. Ong.  Your question, please.

     Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim:  The parents are not able to come to a proper compromise with the bus operator.  Therefore, I would like to request if the Ministry would come in to slaughter this sacred cow which has been there for 30-40 years.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:  Sir, I have to repeat my answer.  We are not responsible for regulating school buses and therefore will not be involved.

Column: 313

SCHOOL BUSES

(Installation of seat belts)

     5.  Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim asked the Minister for Transport whether his Ministry will legislate that all buses that are used to ferry school students be equipped with a seat belt for every seat given that the annual 50% road tax rebate

Column: 314

that is given to these buses will have offset the cost of installing seat belts. 

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:  Sir, Prof. Ong Soh Khim asked for seat belts to be required on all school buses. Let me assure her that we also share her concern about the safety of children travelling in school buses.

 

     Currently, LTA has put in place a comprehensive set of safety measures for school buses which have helped them to achieve a good safety record. As part of the safety requirements, LTA imposes a strict vehicle speed limit of 60 km/h for school buses and requires the buses to undergo compulsory periodic inspections to ensure their roadworthiness.

 

     LTA also requires all school buses with licensed capacity of more than 30 children to have a licensed attendant to look after the safety of the children.  An attendant is also compulsory for all buses carrying young children to kindergartens or childcare centres, regardless of the capacity of the bus.

 

     In addition, since January last year, all newly-registered school buses are required to install automatic hazard lights that blink to warn approaching motorists when the bus stops to pick up or to drop off school children.  These buses must also have a reflective triangular 'Children Crossing' sign with red blinking lights at the rear of the bus. Again, another safety measure.

 

     Sir, as a result of these safety requirements, there have been no cases over the past six years of children suffering serious or fatal injuries while travelling on a school bus. 

 

     Nonetheless, in view of the recent accident involving a school bus, we have asked LTA to review with the Traffic Police the circumstances leading to the accident and also the need to require the

Column: 315

installation of seat belts on school buses.   Members will appreciate that we need to consider this carefully in view of the cost impact on parents using such bus services. Besides the one-time installation costs, this measure will also reduce bus seating capacity. This is because bus seats meant for two adults are currently allowed to seat three children below the age of 12.


This 3:2 seating ratio would not be possible if seat belts are made part of the regulatory requirement, and this is likely to lead to higher school bus fares. 

 

     LTA will also consult stakeholders and take into account other factors, such as other passenger-control measures, accident trends and statistics.

     Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim:  Sir, from my understanding of the LTA website, bus operators can request for a 50% rebate of the annual road tax if they can justify that their buses are substantially used to ferry school students.  My questions are:

 

     (1)  Has there been any misuse of this benefit of the annual 50% rebate by bus operators claiming that they do ferry students while, on the other hand, their buses are being used to ferry operators and so forth?

 

     (2)  Since these buses enjoy a 50% rebate on the annual road tax, would these annual savings of road tax not be able to offset the installation cost of the seat belts?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:  Sir, on the first question, whether there is any abuse by owners of buses while using the 50% rebate, the answer is no, because LTA monitors very closely.  The owners of such buses are required to submit a list of the school children they are carrying and this list is then checked with the school to

Column: 316

make sure that it is a genuine list and not a list of phantom riders.

 

     Sir, on Prof. Ong's second question whether the 50% rebate on road tax would not offset the cost of the installation of seat belts, the 50% rebate is meant to put the owners of these non-school buses on par with the owners of school buses because, as I mentioned earlier, the owners of the school buses are exempted from the COE premiums.

     Mr Speaker:  Prof. Ong, last question.  Be brief, please.

     Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim:  Sir, the Minister said that there has not been any misuse.  I would like to feedback to the Minister that one of the reasons why the bus actually comes and picks up the kids at 11.15 am is that the bus operator's driver claimed that he had to go somewhere to pick up the factory operators and send them to the factory and, therefore, he has no choice but to come and pick up the kids earlier.  So, is the Ministry aware of such practices of the bus transport operators?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:  Sir, the reason why our school bus fares have been kept so low is the ability of the owners to use their buses for multiple journeys.  If they were only to use them for that one trip a day, I am sure the cost of the bus fares would be much, much higher, and this applies to owners of both school buses as well as all owners of non-school buses.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT

 

     Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [17th February, 2006], 

 

     "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 2006 to 31st March, 2007."  -  [Prime Minister and Minister for Finance].

 

     Question again proposed.

     12.18 pm

 

     Mr Ang Mong Seng (Hong Kah) (In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore enjoyed a good economic growth of 6.4% last year, and the prospects for 2006 are also quite optimistic.  This year, the Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Mr Lee Hsien Loong is giving us a $2.6 billion Progress Package which could be said to be pro-senior citizens, pro-low-income workers and pro-National Servicemen.  I could say that this is the most generous Budget since our economic crisis in 1988.  We are all very happy that we could have a share in the fruits of our economic success.

 

     I am sure most people would concur with the principle of giving more grants to the lower-income workers and the lower-income families, and to the elderly.  This incentive bonus is to reward them for their contributions in the past.  However,

Column: 318

on the distribution of this bonus I have three suggestions to make:
     
     First of all, on the topping-up of CPF ElderShield and Medifund, I think we should be reminded of the Chinese maxim: "Whenever we drink water, think of its source."  Topping up of Medisave accounts for the senior citizens is something that we should do.  In the early days of our nation building, this group of Singaporeans, who were then in the prime of their youth, perhaps 20 to 30 years of age, put in a lot of hard work and effort to lift Singapore from a remote Third World country to the developed country it is today, in a rather short span of time.  Our nation building and economic progress is a result of their hard work.  Their contributions to our nation building, development and prosperity are evident for all to see, and we must give credit where it is due.

 

     More than 40 years ago, Singapore and the Southeast Asian countries, such as Malaysia and Indonesia, were all Third World countries which were economically backward.  Many people from the neighbouring countries decided to leave their hometown to migrate to this small island of Singapore.  They were farsighted people.  They realised that with the able leadership of the Government, Singapore would develop very quickly.

 

     In 1957, when I was only seven years old, my father decided to move from Muar in the State of  Johor to Singapore.  At that time, our family lived in Jurong, 18 milestone, in a small kampong two kilometres from the main road, with no electricity supply.  On the first night, even with the kerosene lamp on, the whole place was pitch dark.  We heard a lot of insects and had swarms of mosquitoes around us.  Our whole family could not adapt to such a living environment because we were living in urban Muar before we came here to live in such a rural area.  We were very

Column: 319

unaccustomed to the environment.  We, brothers and sisters, just hugged our mother and cried the whole night, unable to sleep.  But when my father saw this, he told us, "The environment here may not be good, but it is still better than losing your lives."  This was because my father had personally witnessed the type of bloody communal conflicts in Malaya during the 1950s and he knew that although coming to Singapore life would be difficult initially, it was still better than losing our lives.  He said, since we were already in Singapore, we had to work hard in order to earn a better living and to have some achievements.  We accepted our lot, hung on and managed to get used to kampong life.  We did farming, planted a lot of durian trees and rambutan trees.  I know quite a lot about durians.  So, if you want to learn how to choose a durian, you can consult me.

 

     We worked very hard for more than 20 years and in the 1970s when the Government was developing Jurong Town, we were asked to resettle and we accepted the Government's arrangement to move into HDB flats.  With urbanisation, nation-building and economic prosperity, we moved from the kampong to the HDB flats and we began to have water and electricity supply, and our standard of living improved.

 

     Our pioneers have become older and older with the years.  The economic restructuring over the years had a great impact on many of our senior citizens.  It gave rise to a lot of stress and they were unable to adapt to the new situation.  For those who are older, they are unable to get suitable jobs, and when they attend training courses, they find that they are unable to cope with the lessons.  Yet, now we cannot go back to planting vegetables or fruits for food or digging wells for water like in the kampong days.

 

Column: 320

     For the lower-income workers, particularly the older folks, they are facing all sorts of difficulties.  We can understand.  Moreover, nowadays, most families are small.  They do not have the type of mutual support and help provided by larger families in the days gone by.  Nowadays, Singaporeans living in flats may have neighbours on every side, but they are very lonely and have difficulties that they could confide in no one.

 

     All these years, when we receive members of the public who come to apply for ComCare grants, we feel very sorry for the predicament they face.  I think the package comes at the right time.  Although my parents have passed away years ago and are unable to enjoy this package, I treat all the old folks in my constituency as my parents.  I hope that the Government would treat them equally so that all the old folks will benefit from this package.  They have contributed in the past to our nation building and economic development.  Even if they do not have credit, they have merit.  I think we should distribute more of this bonus to the old folks.  We should not use the annual value of the house they live in as the criterion, because sometimes the houses they live in do not belong to them.  To the older folks, we should treat them equally.  We should not classify them into a lower category.  I hope that the Government would give all the old folks above the age of 60 a bonus of $800, and those between 50 and 59 a bonus of $600 each, so that all these senior citizens would be able to enjoy equally the fruits of our economic success.

 

     Secondly, something that is close to my heart, ie, the neighbourhood shops in the HDB estates.  Our neighbourhood shops face a lot of challenges and problems due to the recent economic restructuring.  We must thoroughly study the problems that they face.  Apart from reviewing the existing policy, we should have multi-pronged measures to help

Column: 321

solve their problems.  Due to high rentals, our economy not yet fully recovered, and the termination of their rental rebates since December last year, many of the shops are facing problems surviving, and may even have to close down eventually.

 

     Generally, our economy has recovered somewhat, but the recovery is not even across the board and some of these neighbourhood shops have not really enjoyed the benefits brought about by the economic recovery.  So, if we do not give them a helping hand, I think they will face the risk of having to close down which would cause our residents to suffer a lot of inconvenience.  I hope that we could better empathise with their problems and give them a helping hand to tide them over the difficult times.

 

     The neighbourhood shops are serving residents in the housing estates.  And because the scale of operation cannot be compared to the large shopping centres, naturally, their rentals should not be compared to that of large shopping centres too, we should consider lowering their rentals.  In this time of difficulties, I suggest that the Finance Minister consider extending the 20% rental rebate for another one year.  So long as they have the shops in operation, they would be able to have a better future.  I think this would be a good policy so that they can continue to serve our residents.

     That, Sir, is a lot of money.  More importantly, that money has not been reflected in the Budget.  And it gives a misleading picture of our Government's fiscal position.

 

     Although MOF had defended its 'more stringent definition' of avoiding these 'lumpy uncertain capital receipts', the figures from Appendix 7.1 clearly show that these lumpy amounts of $3-$5 billion have been appearing in quite certain regularity every year, and these should be clearly reflected in our Budget.  I believe everyone here and all accounting experts will agree that all revenues going into the Government's Consolidated Fund must be clearly reflected.  There should be no exception unless mandated by the Constitution.

 

     Not reflecting such big Government capital receipts in the Budget is certainly more misleading to the public than reflecting it, more misleading than what the MOF spokesperson said on a query by the Today paper last Saturday, and I quote:

 

     "... otherwise Singaporeans could be misled about how much revenue is available for expenditure."

 

     Sir, I had been misled.  The public had been misled.  Everyone had been misled to think that the Government budget had been very tight these last four years, and we will enter FY2006 with a huge deficit.  But, Sir, that is not true at all. 

Not reflecting capital receipts is indeed even more misleading than the whole truth. As stated earlier, this Government has more than $19 billion in the Consolidated Fund waiting to be transferred to the reserves. Can the Prime Minister and Finance Minister deny this fact?  We want the truth, nothing but the whole truth.

 

     As Mark Twain ever wrote in his most famous quote, "There are lies, damned

Column: 342

lies, and statistics."  No wonder the IMF, and their report last year, said that Singapore's budget balance underestimates the strength of Singapore's fiscal position.  Now we know why.  Clever statistics have been used.  We can only hope the Government can be more transparent in its disclosures henceforth.

 

     Sir, in view of our better understanding now of total Government receipts, I believe the Government can be a lot more generous.  Generous not only in the element of giving handouts, but also in the aspect of takings.  Mr Low Thia Khiang was right when he said that "only the Government is rich, not the people".  With 60% of households earning below $3,400 per month and the next best 20% of households making only an average of $5,400 per month, how rich can our Singaporean citizens be?  Sir, it is high time to reduce the indirect taxation and fees collected from our people, and allow them to truly grow richer by their efforts - not just from Government dividend handouts.

 

     Table 6.2 of the Budget Highlights shows that "other taxes, other fees and charges, and others" account for $4.36 billion in FY 2004, $3.87 billion in FY 2005, and an estimated $3.97 billion for FY 2006.  These revenue receipts are higher than total GST collections of $3.6 billion and $3.75 billion respectively for each of the following years.  Yet, they are all lumped together as "others" - together with stamp duties, foreign worker levy, etc.

 

     Can Government be more specific about these etc. and etc?  These are not small peanut amount of money that the Government collects.  The total revenue from these "others" is bigger than the revenue collected from the 5% GST, and I think it is important for these others to be more clearly and transparently reflected.

 

Column: 343

     From Appendix 7.1 again, we understand that the Government expects to collect $870 million from stamp duties, $160 million in water conservation tax and $1 billion from "other taxes", although it is not reflected what this "other taxes" is about - that it can amount to actually $1 billion.  I wonder also whether the $111 million collected from the radio and TV licences, as reported last week, is reflected in this $1 billion too.

 

     The point I am driving is this, Sir: that the Government should scrap (or at least drastically reduce) some of these taxes like water conservation tax, radio and TV licences, and domestic foreign worker levy. They can afford to, and they should.

 

      Water is an essential constituent for life.  Without it, we all die. Thus the message to conserve is important.  We do not deny that.  But to impose a "water conservation tax" from the first drop of water coming out from the tap is wrong.  The moment you turn on the tap, the first drop, you are taxed.  That is not good.  People should not be taxed for at least the first 15 cubic metres of water needed for daily necessities and living.  Any taxes imposed on the excess water used above that amount will be reasonable, not below it.

 

     This is especially so since the technology  to produce desalinated water is here, and water is no longer a limited resource, constantly threatened to be cut off by our Malaysian neighbours.  With this new secured source of unlimited water supply from the sea, residents should be charged fair market rate from the provision of such water, and not be imposed such outdated unfair taxes.  I hope the Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources will expedite their reviews and remove it soon.

 

Column: 344

     As for TV and radio licence fees, it is not fair for residents to do national service, and subsidise our national objective of promoting local content developers and providers.  That economic objective should be funded by the Government.  The Government can afford to subsidise more than the current $5 million given for this fledging industry.  Licence fee holders should not be asked to fund this Government objective.  This is an outdated tax and should be reviewed and abolished soon.  Only England, Ireland and some other Commonwealth states continue to impose this licence fee.  Other developed countries, like America, no longer impose such fees to subsidise their national broadcasters.  I hope MICA will act on this soon too.

 

     The Government should also reduce the foreign domestic worker levy, so that the minimum pay of these migrant workers can be raised.  It is incredible that the Government earns more from its levies than the domestic worker herself.  This is cruel, and it profits excessively from the undue hardship of migrant workers.  With better pay, Singaporeans can expect to recruit more experienced maids to look after their families - and not those fresh young maids coming here with psychological problems, adjustment problems, family problems, and with no experience at all working in high-rise flats, contributing to all the murders, suicides and all the careless things that are happening.  The experienced ones are going to Hong Kong and other countries, because of the low pay here, leaving Singapore with all these inexperienced but cheap workers.  Looking at total Government receipts, the Government can well afford to be kinder.

 

     Lastly, Sir, I now want to touch on the Progress Package announced by the Government.  It is good of the Government to return the money back to the people.  I

Column: 345

do not see it as a problem like some other MPs do.  When the Government collects more, then more must be returned to the people.  Period.

 

     On behalf of the people, I thank the Government for heeding my calls (from past budget debates in 2002 through 2005) to return any budget surplus back to the people, to take greater care of our elderly pioneer generation of workers, and to care for the low income and poor - suffering from the high cost of living in our Singapore society.  Thank you, Sir, for heeding our calls.

 

     To all our citizens out there, you can see this is what some of  the things Opposition MPs can do in Parliament - to press the Government to take greater care of you, the citizen, and not take you for granted.

 

     That said, is that all?  Can the Government do better?  I think so.  And I think it should, if it wants greater support from the people.

 

     Firstly, a big group of non-salaried workers are being left out of the Workfare package.  They are the housewives and homemakers.  They work hard 24/7, 365 days to take care of the family (which is the building blocks of our society) and nurture worthy Singaporean citizens with the right values for our society.  Their contribution to Singapore is crucial but it is often neglected, because there are no economic indicators to capture their contribution.

 

     I feel strongly that the Government should include them in this Progress Package and give them the same recognition as we give our NSmen.  They do their national duties by producing babies for our country, sacrifice their career to look after them, and guide them up as proper citizens.  We must appreciate them.  Therefore, I suggest a one-time bonus of $100 per housewife per child, ie, $200 for housewives with

Column: 346

two children, up to a maximum of $400 per housewife with four children or more.  This is to give them some ang-pow spending money for doing a different form of non-financial national service.  It will cost the Government some money, but, again, not something that the Government cannot afford.

 

     Secondly, the whole Workfare package - announced with great fanfare - to help the lowest 20% income earners in our society.  Sir, this is a good scheme.  I support it, and I praise the Government for it.  It only costs the Government $400 million, but it goes a long way to help the estimated 200,000 of low income earners.  A small amount to help a big group of people - that is a brilliant policy!  This is what I would truly call "peanut expenses" compared to the overall total Government expenditure.

 

     Sir, if the Government does not first lead to show care for the poor of our society, nobody can take that initiative to make such a big impact.  As one Australian visitor, Richard Tan, expressed in the Straits Times Forum last week: "Has Singapore become so selfish in its quest for economic prosperity that the poor and the aged get discarded along the way?"   I hope not.  And I believe not.  With this new Workfare package, it is a big shift in the Government's policy on welfare.  And I want to credit our Prime Minister Lee for his bold step in that direction.  The rich and well-off in our society must help the poor and low income in our society, through the redistribution of wealth by the Government.  Everyone who wants to work must get a decent comfortable income from it.  Therefore, I beseech the Government to finetune this Workfare programme into a yearly programme, possibly through the use of negative income tax (NIT).

 

     In today's term, the cost of living and the wages of the low income workers

Column: 347

have not risen proportionately.  The cost of utilities, public transport and housing have all risen tremendously by profit-centred businesses whereas  the wages of the low-income unskilled workers are artificially depressed by increasing supply of low and semi-skilled migrant workers coming here to compete for jobs.

 

     We need to raise the earnings of the non- and semi-skilled Singaporean workers.  We need a more sustained effort at improving their lot.  As some MPs had also agreed earlier, help must be given on a more consistent and sustainable basis, not just in the run-up to a general election where the one-off cash handouts will be spent in no time.

 

     The Government can well afford to spend up to a maximum $500 million every year to generate tax credits for every aged working citizen above 45 years, earning below the minimum income of $1,200 per month.  On a tiered basis, it will go a long way to help the really poor in our midst.  If the Government is genuinely more caring now, I, like Mdm Halimah, challenge the Government to install this Workfare programme every year, not just at an election year.

 

     Thirdly, and most importantly, the Government needs to incentivise help for the young family.  Our modern society and family are being attacked by the onslaught of decaying moral values through the mass and digital medium.  Parents no long know what their teenage children are doing, and even if they do know, they no longer have the power to control nor influence them.  What we read in the papers of late, and even today, of some parents who do not even know that their children sneak out of the house in the middle of the night, are but the surface cream of more trouble brewing underneath with our teens in our society. 

 

Column: 348

     Our values are being badly eroded, and our youths grow up lost, disoriented and led by peers with less than proper character. Young parents really need help bringing up their children. And this guidance cannot be coming from childcare centres, maids or schools.  It must come from the family - in the person of the parents and the grandparents.

 

     The Government urgently needs to provide greater fiscal incentives for grandparents, and even mothers, to consider quitting their outside jobs to spend quality and quantity time with their children and grandchildren, especially in the first seven years of development.  If we seriously care for our families and society, 10 to 20 years down the road, we need to act now - immediately.

 

     Mothers need to consider giving up their job for their children and family, if necessary.  Husbands and fathers need to spend more love and attention on their family, other than chasing the economic dole. Grandmothers must be encouraged, through limited Government subsidies, to provide home-based infant and childcare - something that I had mentioned at the last budget too.

 

     To subsidise the cost of childcare through grandparents is a big paradigm shift.  It is a shift that we can no longer afford not to take  The right and proper family authority and guidance must be established to guide the growing youths from being led astray in our society.  The Government can help in a big way.  I hope that MCYS will review this proposal fast and give a satisfactory reply in the COS debate.

 

     In conclusion, Sir, this is a good Budget.  Returning money to the people is always good, albeit for the wrong motives.  I support this Budget even though it comes with personal political expense.  This could be my last Budget debate here in the House if I am not

Column: 349

elected at the next coming General Election.  I, therefore, hereby wish all colleagues and citizens the best of wishes for the coming year.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (East Coast): Mr Speaker, I am afraid I will be disappointing the House as I would not be able to match Mr Steve Chia's fire and fury.

 

     Sir, about two weeks ago, a Malaysian Minister caused a little flap in business circles here when he accused Singapore traders of rebranding his country's products and relabelling them as Singapore ones. As an example, he referred to Malaysian rambutans being exported to Hongkong as Singapore lychees.  In other words, we were exploiting an agricultural produce of his country in a way to benefit Singapore. I think the people of Hongkong, well known for their discerning tastes when it comes to food, and being able to get abundant supplies of fresh and good quality lychees  from China and Thailand, would be the last people on earth to fall for rambutans passing off as lychees.  Fortunately, the Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority of Singapore has investigated the matter and concluded that there is no truth in the accusation, be it of fruits, ornamental fish, or flowers, being passed off as Singapore's own.

 

     But this incident made me think that there is more to it than a simple case of unfounded accusation. Trade issues are always a sensitive matter in economic relations between countries.  I think that even if our traders do not indulge in any such malpractices - there are strict WTO rules that prohibit this - this incident must say a lot about the unease that the Singapore name can cause when it comes to trade matters.  Unease because the Singapore brand is strong, and it strikes fear in those who compete with us, or

Column: 350

perhaps there is a case of pure envy of how far we have come.

 

     Take the failure of Singapore Airlines to get the right to fly from Sydney to Los Angeles from the Australian Government.  Is it really, as the Australians say, that opening up the Pacific route offers no benefit to Australia, or is it simply a protectionist measure to shelter Qantas from competition?  The Australians have mastered the art of telling the world with a straight face that giving Singapore Airlines the right to fly once a day on the lucrative Pacific route, where there is a shortage of seats and where prices have been kept artificially high for the consumers, would cause Qantas to axe jobs, affect its status as one of the most profitable airlines in the world and, even as they claimed, cause Qantas to go bankrupt.

 

     Yet, as has been reported, the Australians are quite happy to allow their own budget carrier, Virgin Blue, to fly this route instead.  One must therefore presume that the Australians have, in the same breath, concluded suddenly that Qantas can now survive competition, as long as that competition comes from one of their own.

 

      Is this not an admission by the Australians of their inability to compete with SIA's much lauded inflight service, and does it not boil down to a case of looking after their own parochial interests?  Anyone who has flown SIA and Qantas can tell the difference between the quality of service provided by the two.  Qantas can be not too bad at times - if they want to - but most people would tell you without hesitation which airline consistently comes up tops.

 

     So it is the same old story again.  When you feel the heat from the competition, you put up the barriers.  Our competitors know that the Singapore

Column: 351

name has done well.  The Singapore brand has gained a strong reputation in the world.  Whatever we do, we strive to do it well, in fact, some might say, too well, that our competitors envy or fear us, but they cannot bring it on themselves to compete with us on a level playing field.

 

     In Europe, an Indian gentleman by the name of Mr Lakshmi Mittal is causing an uproar in political circles.  His company, Mittal Steel, is the world's largest steel producer and he wants to make it even bigger by merging it with Arcelor, Europe's largest steel maker in a deal that would cost him about US$23 billion.  Mr Mittal is facing obstacles.  He has infuriated governments in Europe. Never mind that he has built his company to become number one in the world as long as it remains outside of Europe.  The refrain running through much of Europe seems to be: how can this man, what more an Indian, take on the Europeans?  The Finance Minister of France, Mr Thierry Breton, is quoted as having said that Mr Mittal has a grammar problem, implying that his linguistic imperfections must be a serious barrier to his ability to run an European operation.  Such a statement displays the European's xenophobia and betrays their cultural or, even worse, racial prejudices.  All rationale and economic arguments for a merger that would benefit consumers in over half the world - Mr Mittal's steel interests extend from China through the Asian continent to the United States - and all hitherto pontifications on the part of the Europeans of their commitment to a free trade and to a free flow of investments have been thrown to the wind.  So much for free trade agreements.

 

     Across the Atlantic another group of investors is also causing a stir elsewhere, this time in the United States.  Having now successfully bid for P&O, Dubai Ports World, the investment arm of the United

Column: 352

Arab Emirates, will end up managing some of the most important ports in the world, including half a dozen ports in the United States.  American legislators are up in arms over this, citing security concerns over their ports being managed by a company controlled by a foreign country, never mind if it is a country that has been America's close ally in its fight again terrorism.  Nor did it matter to them to reason why it was all right for them when P&O, which was until now a British company, managed the same US ports.  One can well imagine that we could have encountered similar hostility if we had won our bid for P&O.

 

     The failed bid by China National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC) to acquire American oil giant Unocal in August last year is another case in point.  American lawmakers argued that it was just too sensitive a matter for a State backed Chinese company to acquire a hold on valuable and strategic American energy assets.  The Chinese assured the Americans that this was a purely commercial transaction, an acquisition of a company that in fact has most of its assets outside the US, and that in any case it was prepared to dispose of the US-based assets if the deal came through.  Another assurance by CNOOC that the takeover, unlike that of the rival bid from Chevron, would not result in any job losses, did not cut any ice with US legislators who wanted to block the deal.  Even though its bid of US$18.5 billion was way above the US$17.6 billion bid from Chevron, CNOOC's attempt was frustrated by the US lawmakers and, in the end, the Chinese decided to walk away from the whole thing.  To the Americans, the maths just did not matter.

 

     I recount all this to point out that we live in a sensitive world where trade and political tensions still and will continue to simmer.  In an era of globalisation and trade liberalisation and free trade agreements notwithstanding, there are

Column: 353

still those who, while subscribing to the principles of trade liberalisation, succumb to their own narrow interests when the crunch comes, and domestic political considerations come first at the expense of sound economic sense.  To some Americans and Europeans, it is a case of "you play the game by our rules".  It is easy, Sir, for the Australians to tell us that the SIA issue will not affect broader ties but Singaporeans are angry with the outcome.  For a long time, the Australian's position dangled between one of reticence to giving us an occasional dash of hope, but in the end having got all the fifth freedom rights they wanted from us, and knowing that we have no more bargaining chips left on the table, they led us on a 10-year run around.  The Singapore lion was simply outforced by the wily Australian kangaroo.  Maybe we were not canny enough.  A successful Singapore company has not been allowed to engage in a fair fight for the consumer dollar.  A man from India, Arabs from the Middle East, and entrepreneurs from China are not supposed to disrupt the Western order of things, no matter what the economic rationale is.

 

     A writer to the Straits Times' Forum page yesterday summed it best when he wrote, and I quote: "The West, used to cultural and economic pre-eminence on the international stage, suddenly finds its position under threat by the unstoppable growth of a dynamic Asia.  The West is unable to accept that it will soon be overtaken by the emergence of Asian powerhouses and fears that it will become irrelevant in an increasingly globalised world it refused to wake up to.  Thus, in a desperate bid to avoid the inevitable, the West seeks to use whatever means available, sometimes even in contravention of internationally agreed norms, to suppress the growth of Asian economies wherever possible."

 

    Sir, our businessmen will continue to straddle the globe to look for

Column: 354

opportunities.  Most of the time, they will come across a conducive environment abroad because our Government has negotiated and paved the way for close economic and political ties, but once in a while they can expect the unexpected and encounter hostility.  Our economic success will be shaped by our own determination and our ability to be innovative and daring, but we must continue to ensure that we can play by fair rules and that our efforts are not stymied by those who continue to use unfair practices when it suits them.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir):  Thank you, Sir, for allowing me to join in the debate.  Sir, I am not a cynic.  I know the realities of politics, especially politics in Singapore, and I say that this Budget is an Election Budget.  All the signs are there. 

 

     The PAP's aim is to win the election this time with convincing results equal to or not better than the record of  75.1% achieved in the 2001 election so as to give the standing of the new leadership a big boost.  It shall then have more authority with a strong mandate from the people to deal with matters locally and those abroad with greater confidence. 

     However, it is difficult for the PAP to repeat the 2001 election results.  I sense that the ground is different this time round.  Currently, more people are talking earnestly that they want more Opposition in Parliament, especially the young and more educated Singaporeans.  Their desire for more Opposition representation in Parliament is hard to change. 

 

     For this reason, the PAP's tactic is to target the poor and the elderly.  Financially, they are the worse off group in Singapore and are vulnerable to monetary handouts by the Government.  The Government's timing is right.  Despite

Column: 355

the Government's claim that the economy is recovering and a drop of unemployment rate from 4.2% a few years back to the current 2.4%, the effects of the recession are still felt now by the workers.  Any monetary help from the Government at this point of time to the poor and the aged shall be readily welcomed.  The Government knows of this fact and the use of the Budget at this time round for election purposes is fully exploited.  The tactic is awesome.  The tactic used is like a military assault - massive and precisely targeted.

Column: 356

not have been disbursed even at the expense of incurring a deficit.

 

     What is interesting also is that the much-publicised practice of the Government is done away with in the way money is paid out under this Budget.  The practice of the Government has been almost never to give subsidies, financial assistance or monetary handouts without a co-payment being made by the recipient of the Government's monetary gifts.  So, in 2001, when the Government allotted the New Economic Restructuring Shares and the New Singapore Shares to Singaporeans, they had first to co-pay $50 before those shares could be handed to them.  It was reported that as many as 100,000 Singaporeans did not pay the required $50 into their CPF accounts and they were not allotted the New Singapore Shares.  This time around, because the exercise is to win votes, the payments out of monies under the Growth Dividends and the Workfare Bonus need not be accompanied by any co-payment.  This, I believe, the Government wants is to make sure all Singaporeans receive payments under the Growth Dividends and Workfare Bonus schemes so that they may be influenced to vote the PAP.

 

     I would like to report a feedback on the Workfare Bonus.  This scheme, according to some people, seems to discourage hard work.  I was told of a worker who earns $1,200 a month basic and since he has a wife and three infant children to take care of, he worked very hard and did plenty of overtime to increase his earnings.  His gross salary jumped to $2,500 and, because the upper limit of his income exceeds the upper limits of $1,200 and $1,500, he is not allowed to claim the Workfare Bonus.  That worker is very angry at the way the Workfare Bonus is framed.  The Government, on the one hand, tells Singaporeans to work hard, yet, when this worker puts in more hours and earns more money, he is disqualified from

Column: 357

receiving his Workfare Bonus.  I do not think the Workfare Bonus scheme is fair to this category of hardworking Singaporeans.

     Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim (In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in this debate on the Budget Statement.

 

     First of all, I support the financial policy and the Budget announced in Parliament by the Prime Minister in his capacity as the Minister for Finance for the new fiscal year, to build a vibrant economy where opportunities are everywhere and an inclusive society where no one is left behind.  Allow me to raise a few suggestions and observations.

     In this year's Budget, the Government has introduced a Progress Package amounting to $2.6 billion.  This package includes the Growth Dividend, Workfare Bonus and the National Service Bonus.  With regard to the $1.4 billion worth of Growth Dividend to all adult Singaporeans, I would like to make a few suggestions.  This Growth Dividend is computed according to each citizen's annual income and the annual value of the house that he lives in.  Each person will receive an amount of between $200 and $800, with the middle and lower-income families getting the biggest benefits.  Singaporeans only need to fill in a form or make an application through the ATM or

Column: 358

website by 1st April 2006 and they will receive the Growth Dividend by 1st May 2006.

 

     In past years, we saw many generous and well-off Singaporeans who cashed their New Singapore Shares and Economic Restructuring Shares, and donated the proceeds to poor and needy Singaporeans.  This year, these well-off Singaporeans may not claim their Growth Dividends, so we will have some amounts of unclaimed dividends which have been budgeted for.  Although the amount may not be very great, it would also go a long way to help the poor and needy people in our society.
