After using it to pay their bus fares, they may have no money to buy food during the recess. Moreover, when they have to stay behind for core-curricula activities or remedial classes, some of them may not have the money to buy their lunches.  Although the Straits Times has already set up a Pocket Money Fund, it would be good for an individual pocket money fund to be set up for each of the neighbourhood schools. These schools know their students well and are in a better position to extend their help to those who are genuinely in need.
 
     My second suggestion is that we should distribute some of the unclaimed

Column: 359

Growth Dividends to the old folks' homes and day-care centres.  In Singapore, most of the old folks' homes and day-care centres operated by voluntary welfare organisations are running at a loss.  Among the inmates of these old folks' homes, some of them are lonely, single old people and some of them are displaced parents.  No matter what job they did during their younger days, they have contributed in one way or another to our nation-building.  Singapore does not advocate a welfare system, so we cannot provide welfare to these lonely old people.  But if we can make use of some of these unclaimed Growth Dividends to help them, why not?

 

     This year's Budget is very generous and it takes care of the immediate problems of the older and lower-income workers.  But there is one group of people who have been perpetually neglected.  They are the middle or lower-income singles, particularly those who are middle-aged. 

 

     The middle or lower-income singles, particularly those who are middle-aged, face all sorts of problems. Singapore society now is aging.  By 2030, almost 19% of our population will be 65 years and above.  With an aging population, smaller families and lower fertility rate, there will be fewer family members with the means to maintain their older folks.  The probability of the single persons having to bear a heavy burden to look after their old folks without helps from siblings is higher.  This Budget does not help them in this respect.  I hope that we could provide the followings to help the people to maintain their old folks:


     (1)  A higher tax relief for maintenance of parents, particularly those who need long-term medical treatment;

     (2)  Paid eldercare leave to take their parents to hospital or clinic, since they

Column: 360

cannot afford to have maids to look after their parents; and

 

     (3)  More subsidies to help with the charges of the old folks' homes or day-care centres so that these lower-income people could send their parents to the old folks' homes or day-care centres, and they can then go to work with a peace of mind.

 

    The single people also have a lot of problems when it comes to housing.  In this year's Budget, the Government will spend $75 million to provide additional CPF Housing Grant to the lower-income families to help them own their flats.  But this would have no effect on the lower-income singles.  According to Census 2000, 15.8% of the people between the age of 15 and 44 are single.  With some 650,000 people in this age group, there are in fact as many as 100,000 single men and women.  For those who are below 35 years of age, they will have to form a family unit jointly with their parents before they can apply to buy a new HDB flat.  HDB will occasionally sell some of their new flats to the singles, but they are sold to them at market rates.  Moreover, the singles do not qualify for concessionary interest rates for their housing loan.  Those whose income is $3,000 and above will not qualify for the $11,000 housing grant and they cannot apply to the HDB for the concessionary loan.  I think this is unfair to the singles, particularly the middle or lower-income singles.

 

      First, these middle and lower-income singles remain single not by choice but due to circumstances beyond their control.  No matter what job they are doing, they have been contributing to Singapore.  But when it comes to buying a flat from HDB, they are treated unequally.  There is a middle-aged single lady in my place of work.  She is 40 years old and working as a general clerk.  When she wanted to purchase an HDB flat, she

Column: 361

had to buy from the resale market and it is much more expensive than buying direct from HDB.  Her salary is not too low, yet not too high either.  Hence, she cannot apply for a HDB loan and has to take a bank loan.  Because she is buying a second-hand flat, she has also to spend a lot of money to renovate it before she could move in.

       In Singapore, there are many middle-aged single people, men and women, who are facing these problems.  Generally, in Singapore, if both the husband and wife are working, they need about 20-30 years before they can clear their housing loan.  For a single person, he or she will have to spend a longer time before the housing loan could be fully discharged.  The unfair treatment when purchasing HDB flats causes many problems to the middle and lower-income single people, and they feel that they have been discriminated against.  This middle-aged lady in my place of work asked me, "Why must I be penalised just because I am not married and have not produced children for the nation?" This feeling is not limited to middle-aged women, many other middle-aged men have the same feeling too!

 

     Secondly, I think it is not practical to insist that a single person must apply together with their parents, as some single persons' parents could have already passed away.  Those parents who are still alive would, more often than not, choose to stay with the married children so that they can look after the grandchildren. These single persons are unable to form a family unit and they cannot apply for new flats from HDB.

      Thirdly, there may be suggestions that these singles can stay with their brothers or sisters, and there is no need for them to buy their own flats.  But we all know that the HDB flats are getting smaller and smaller, and married brothers or sisters who have their own families will not have

Column: 362

a spare room for these uncles and aunties to stay in.  Even if there is a spare room, when the nephews and nieces have grown up, they will need a room for themselves, and these uncles and aunties will have to move out after all.

  

   Fourthly, the HDB's rule is that for a single person to rent a one-room flat from HDB, he would have to apply jointly with another single person as he cannot apply for one unit for himself. Why is the HDB insisting that two total strangers should "cohabit" with each other just to apply for the flat?  This would create a lot of problems.  I think there are frequent reports in the papers of problems arising from these circumstances.

 

    Fifthly, there are rumours that some lower-income single men, in order to buy their own flats, would just go overseas and conveniently take a bride in order to form a family unit to apply for the flats. These foreign brides are causing some new social problems in Singapore.  Has our so-called pro-family home ownership policy added on unnecessary stress on our lower-income singles resulting in the creation of new social problems?

     Sixthly, the pro-family policy is to encourage people to get married and have children.  But we can see that it is not making much headway.  The trend that many Singaporeans (not only the women, the men too) did not marry is not because they are too highly-educated, but is due to a strings of problems, such as an unbalance in the gender roles in the families,  no financial means to support and bring up their children.

 

     Singapore has progressed and modernised. The education level of Singaporeans has also risen. It is no longer the Singapore of the 70s and 80s.  Nowadays, many people have gone overseas to work or study. When they come back, many of them are beyond the

Column: 363

age of 35 years old, still remaining single. Many have missed the boat for courtship and marriage due to work or study.  Hence I have to declare that I am not advocating singlehood.  All I am saying is that the housing problems that come about with their remaining single are part of the new modernisation process - something that is inevitable.  We should adjust our existing policies to look after them.  We cannot remain like an ostrich which buries its head in the sand and ignores the existence of the singles.  Has our pro-family housing policy, which aims to encourage young Singaporeans to marry in order to purchase new HDB flats, fallen behind times? The Ministry has said that Singaporeans can apply to the HDB for waiver based on their special circumstances. However, if there are so many Singaporeans applying for waiver, does it mean that our pro-family is our-dated, and it is time to amend this policy? Our pro-family policy, encouraging marriages and procreation, should be adjusted in accordance with the changes, to enable the singles to buy new flats at the normal HDB prices.  I would like to make two suggestions:

     One is to allow lower and middle-income singles to buy new flats at the HDB prices.  Many of these middle-aged people have reached a certain age and whatever pressure you put on them, they would not get married.  This is a fact.  Like in my workplace, there is a middle-aged lady.  She told me that she is no longer pretty and could not possibly give birth to children.  She would not contemplate getting married.  She told me that she was used to the life of a single and would not get married just for the sake of getting a flat.  Our procreation policy is irrelevant to her.  Hence, I hope the HDB can consider allowing middle and lower-income middle-aged singles to buy HDB flats at HDB prices.

 

Column: 364

      The HDB is considering the building of retirement village. In this regard, I would like to raise my second suggestion, which is that perhaps HDB can reserve some units in this retirement village for purchase by singles. I passed by a retiree village during my visit to New Zealand last year. I was in a special bus that took the passengers from the airport to their destination. When the bus passed through the retiree village, my impression was that this was a very quiet place with no life or vibrancy in it.  If we allow younger singles to buy some of the units in the village, then they will bring life and vigour into the village, and also help to look after these old people. By allowing these singles and the older people to stay in the same retirement villages, the retirement village can become a better place with the structure of a family although there is no direct family relationships between these singles and older people.

      Lastly, I would like to talk about the status of women in Singapore.  There is a group of people in Singapore who seems to be neglected, they are the Singaporean women, especially the unmarried single women.  In this year's Budget, we have a Progress Package, comprising the Growth Dividend, Workfare Bonus, NS Bonus and so on.  If we combine this year's package to packages in the previous years, including baby bonus, marriage, procreation package, foreign maid levy, rebate for married women and so on, then everybody in Singapore seems to get some kind of benefit from the Budget in recognition of their contribution to the country.  Only the female citizens, especially the single female citizens, despite whatever contributions that they had made to Singapore, do not seem to be duly recognised.

 

      Since 1965, the conservative and traditional nature of our society has become a marked contrast to our modernisation and economic develop

Column: 365

ment.  Singapore has become an Asian city with a modern outlook, but a relatively conservative and patriarchal society.  The social status of women in Singapore remains not too high.  In Singapore, the materialistic lives of our women have apparently improved. However, compared to their male counterparts, the women do not seem to be affirmed and elevated as far as social, economic and political status is concerned.  Singapore has consistently taken strict control of the social ideology, flying the flag of upholding values of Oriental traditional culture to counter the onslaught of westernisation and modernisation, and this includes resistance to the elevation of social, economic and political status of the women vis-Ã-vis the men. 

     Why do I say so?  Take, for example, the political status of the women vis-Ã-vis the men.  There was a recent newspaper report that a certain Minister said that the PAP would field more than 10 female MPs in the next election, and that there was "progress".  Why should it be called "progress", rather than "as it should be"?  Does this not show that we are still having a deeply patriarchal society here in Singapore?  Is this not an indication that the Singapore women would have to stand by the margin and try to integrate into the patriarchal social system by working silently by themselves?

    The Singapore Government seems to feel that the Singapore women should consider themselves lucky for not being among the women folks of Japan, Korea or India.  The Government seems to be sending out a message though its policy that female citizens of Singapore ought to be contented with their present situation whereby they can walk out of the kitchen and get into the main hall, and that they could have a happy family and an income that could make them self-reliant.  This may not be the actual message that the Government and the Cabinet wish to send

Column: 366

out, but it is the kind of message that many Singapore women have "heard".

 

    While appealing for the female citizens to walk out of the comfort zone of their homes, to take upon the citizens' obligations and to join the workforce, the GovenrmentGovernment is also insisting that the women folks should not abandon their traditional roles as wives and mothers.  For example, the female employees are provided with the flexi-work hour system and thereby enabling them to get married and bear children - for posterity of the nation.  Only then, would they be deemed to have contributed to the nation, and be affirmed and endorsed by the Government to enjoy benefits like tax relief, baby bonus, etc, under the Budget packages.  But, for those female citizens who are single and have not produced any children, apart from the basic Growth Dividend, they do not get any other form of recognition.  The Government does not seem to recognise that the female citizens, although not having done National Service, have also made contributions to the nation.

     After the 90s, the awareness of independence and freedom from domestic responsibilities has gradually been formed amongst the women of Singapore.  They refused to get married, refused to have children, while actively pursuing their careers.  The Government introduced various measures to encourage female undergraduates to get married and have children after their graduation.  The Social Development Unit was formed.  Childcare centres were set up extensively, flexi-work hours were provided for female employees, procreation incentives were given, more time-off for husbands to visit their wives in confinement, and even paid leave for fathers to look after their sick children.  But these measures are fundamentally built on the basic viewpoint that family obligations are the bounden duties of women.  So the women have not been given true equality.  This does not go to the root of the problem.  It will

Column: 367

not effectively resolve the problem of low fertility rate in Singapore.

 

     Singapore women's social obligations are generally becoming heavier and heavier, with no likelihood of relieving themselves of their families' obligations.  They have to contend with three layers of pressure from their personal, family and social obligations. We should find some ways to help them get out of this predicament.  Many working women have told me that having worked hard for an entire day, they would still have to tend to the household chores when they reached home. Even helping their children with the school homework is also considered to be part of their duty.  If we cannot address these problems faced by women with regard to family, work and society responsibilities and obligations, and implement concrete measures, then it will be very difficult for Singaporean women to maintain a between family and work and yet remain true to themselves.

     I hope that the Government will look at the basic social structure and value, and create a new society where there is a balance in the gender roles. I have to declare that  I am not a feminist.  I am only proposing that the Government uses a more gender balance approach when proposing and implementing new policies. What I am asking for is to have a better balance between the male and the female citizens in our society.

 

     The women of Singapore are grateful to Minister Mentor Mr Lee Kuan Yew for giving the female citizens of  Singapore equal opportunities to be educated and to find better employment during the 1960s. Since they have been given equal opportunities to be educated and to secure good employment, then why can we go one step forward to give all female citizens equal status as their male

Column: 368

counterparts in society, the economy and in politics?
 

    As a newly emerging city-state, the important issue is how do we let the womenfolks who hold up half the sky give full play to their capabilities.  This is one issue that relates to our social harmony and national development and prosperity.  The realisation of social harmony and national development depends not only on political stability, strong economic growth, formidable defence and religious harmony, equality and tolerance, but also on the equality and harmony between the sexes.

 

     In a speech entitled "Oriental and Western Culture and Modernisation" delivered at the "China Science and Humanities Forum" organised by the China Science Academy in 2004, Minister Mentor Lee said, "In the past, I felt that I have to bear the responsibility of allowing all female citizens of Singapore equal opportunities to be educated and the best job opportunities in the 1960s, resulting in the phenomenon of many female university graduates not getting married subsequently.  Now, I believe I was merely bringing the phenomenon forward by some two decades or so."  Yes, Minister Mentor Mr Lee Kuan Yew does not need to take responsibility for this because this is an inevitable phenomenon in the process of modernisation of the nation and the society.  I personally feel that, at the present moment, there are many policies and measures that are inclined towards the male perspective.  The lack of a feminine angle in the system and the imbalanced family structure are the critical factors that cause the economically-independent females to avoid getting married and reject the duty of procreation.

     I hope the Government will consider the points I have raised concerning the status of women in Singapore.  I hope that the Government will immediately

Column: 369

start to focus on this trend, and adjust some of its policies so that they could take off from the angle of equality between the sexes thereby affirming and elevating the status of the women vis-a-vis the men.

 

     Finally, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his fiscal policy and this Budget to build up an inclusive society where no one is left behind, so that Singapore will become the best home for all its citizens.

      

2.15 pm

 

     Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Aljunied) (In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, on this Budget, all the three Opposition Members, Mr Low Thia Khiang, Mr Chiam See Tong and Mr Steve Chia, are behaving like what the Teochew would say: "When you did not have any, you would complain that you had not; but now that you have some, you will still find fault with what has been given to you."


     They claimed they were looking at it from the workers' point of view.  However, it was reported in yesterday's Straits Times that views from various quarters, ranging from the President of the Contractors' Association to the ordinary workers, were that this was a pro-business and pro-worker Budget.  Having provided for the business community and the workers, we are able to satisfy the needs of our people.  This Budget provides for various packages, schemes and grants which not only benefit the workers directly, but also fall in line with the workers' expectation of more job opportunities to be created.  The Workfare Bonus, together with the NTUC's Job Recreation Scheme will directly alleviate the workers' burden.  It will also upgrade their low-paying jobs, improve the standard of living of the low-income workers in a practical way.

 

     I am sure the three Opposition Members know this, but they just refuse

Column: 370

to accept it.  But members of the public generally look only at the ang pows and overlook the other packages, and some members of the public are even asking if this Budget is deviating from the general principle of the past Budgets.

 

     I have a friend who told me the Coca Cola story and suggested that we draw a lesson from it.  Mr Speaker, Sir, in the early 80s, the Coca Cola Company conducted a series blindfold tasting test.  In other words, the people participating in the survey were blindfolded and were asked to randomly taste two drinks.  The company discovered that many of those who took part in the tests preferred the sweeter Pepsi Cola.  As a result, the company made a very absolute decision and introduced the new Coca Cola.  In the new Coca Cola, they reduced the traditional ingredients and made it sweeter.  But this so-called "thorough" change was a "thorough" failure because people like Coca Cola not because it is sweeter than Pepsi Cola, but because of its traditional taste.  So, in the end, Coca Cola Company has to recall all the new Coca Cola and reintroduced the classic Coke.  So in this Budget, are we, to a certain extent, deviating from our past prudent and pragmatic principle of budgeting?  I believe not, and I am sure the Prime Minister will clarify this doubt.

     The purpose of this Budget obviously is to increase our economic competitiveness and to push our infocommuncations technology, intellectual property, research and development, maritime and logistics industries to a higher peak and to recreate our economy in such a way that we will be able to give more emphasis to our manufacturing and service industries, and provide more support and help to our lower-income workers. This is very important.  I am sure, with all these schemes, more workers would benefit.

 

     In the past, when I heard this song, I could not understand the meaning of its

Column: 371

lyrics which said, "Loving you may lead to hurting you."  Yesterday, having heard what Mr Low Thia Khiang had said, I began to appreciate the message.  If we just resort to sweet talks to please the workers, we are not loving them, but rather we are harming them.  They keep saying that our workers are suffering and they cannot find jobs.  Yet, all they do is mere talking but nothing is done to address the problem.  This is lip service, and rubbing salt into the wounds.  It may be good in winning over the support of the people, but it is meaningless. 

     In the end, we have to do like what the labour movement is doing.  We examine the needs of the people and prescribe the right medicine for their needs.  The NTUC has worked very hard in fostering our labour, employer and Government tripartite cooperation to tackle the unemployment problem.  This is the correct medicine.

 

     There is a Chinese saying, "a mantis trying to stop a chariot using its arms", that is, to over-rate itself by attempting something impossible.  How can we stop the global trend of development?  To a very large extent, we need to help our older workers.  We cannot expect the industry to lower their standard or restrain its development to suit the lower-skilled workers who could not cope with the changes.  What we can do is to find practical ways to help our older workers upgrade their skills so that they can retain their income. Most importantly, in this year's Budget, we have provided more assistance to the children of the lower income families so that they can receive better education in order to eventually get out of poverty.

     We all understand what are the problems facing us today.  The older workers have difficulty getting jobs.  According to the Ministry of Manpower's

Column: 372

statistics, the unemployment rate for the older workers is about 6% and it takes a longer time for them to fit into a new job.  I think we must first of all understand their problems and help them to stand up on their own.  Through the various schemes, we want to help them to continue being employed.  We must also understand what are the problems faced by each and every one of the unemployed workers and guide them so that they know where they could look for solutions to solve their problem. 

 

     We cannot say, "Oh, let us have more protectionist policies and ban companies from moving overseas.  We want the companies to stay in Singapore forever to provide job opportunities for our workers."  We all know that this is impossible.

     During the transitional period, we must let the workers understand that they must accept the challenges and accept lower paid jobs as it is better than to be unemployed. This is the principle behind the Workfare Bonus.  We want to cheer up our workers.  Let them know that although their income at the current moment may be lower, so long as they have a job, there is a hope of eventually earning a better income and a better standard of living.

 

     We cannot do like what Mr Steve Chia has recommended just now by asking the Government to draw out all the money from the reserves to help the workers.  This is a sure way to bankrupt our Government.  We all know that this is not feasible.  What are we going to do if we run out of money?  So, more importantly, we have to help our Singaporeans to stand up.  I am sure all the people in Singapore do not want to just sit there and stretch out their hands to wait for handouts from the Government.  I know that all the workers in Singapore prefer to be taught how to fish rather than being given the fish.  

Column: 373

     Mr Speaker, Sir, the Finance Minister should also help to clear the doubts of some Singaporeans as some of them are worried that this package of $2.6 billion would in some way reduce the Government's capability to carry out all its projects and services to our people.  Many people have this doubt.  I am sure this will not be.  I am sure that the Government must have thought out all the implications before arriving at such a decision to share the fruits of economic success with the people.  The Government knows, as a fact,  that education, defence, medical service, etc., are very important to our people. 

 

     The only thing that I am disappointed with is that the Government has not provided more money for Medifund.  Of course many people are happy with the plan to build more 2-room flats and the extra housing grants for the lower-income workers.  This is a shot in the arm as they would otherwise not be in a position to own their own homes.  In fact, Singapore is the only country in the world that could attain the idealistic realm, as painted in the famous poetry of the great Tang Dynasty poet, Du Fu, "Having millions of homes and bringing shelter and happiness to people all over."  We have actually achieved "home-ownership for everyone".

     But with this trend of globalisation, we may need to make some adjustments to our existing "Home for Everyone" scheme.  I notice that for the younger generation nowdays, the moment they get married they would want to purchase an HDB flat straightaway, and start bearing the burden of a housing loan.  If the Government can provide some rental flats as an alternative, they may consider buying a flat later on, perhaps only after they have children.  It is still not too late.  Then, they would not have to immediately bear this heavy housing loan the moment they get married.  I hope the Government will consider this.

 

Column: 374

     As far as healthcare is concerned, we know that once a worker has lost his job he would have lost his medical benefit.  The NTUC has all along been advocating the concept of portable medical benefits.  This will enable the workers to retain their medical benefits even after they have left their job.  If the workers do not have portable medical benefits, they would have to make use of their Medisave accounts.  Many workers may not have used their medical benefits in their younger days.  One simple way is to allow the unused medical benefits to be saved up.  The Government should consider setting up a new account so that employers could make additional contributions to this account and the employees would be able to make use of it in times of need, or even to pay the premium for their medical insurance.  If it is not used, the amount in the account will remain, and when they get old they could make use of this money to pay for their medical expenses. 

     Generally speaking, in this trend of globalisation we have to be more flexible.  We cannot just turn a deaf ear to the problems.  There is a Chinese proverb which says, "Close you ears and steal the bell".  This is not the right way to do things.  We should not ask the Government to prohibit our companies from relocating overseas.  This is not practical.  What we need to do is to create a conducive pro-business environment so as to attract more investors to come here to invest and thereby creating more jobs for our people.

 

     There has been a suggestion that we should have a minimum wage provision to prevent the employers from exploiting our workers.  This so-called minimum wage policy is practised in some countries.  But we can say for sure that, eventually, it is the workers who will suffer.

     Let me give you a very simple example and you will understand.  When the

Column: 375

Philippine government ruled that all Filipino maids should be given a minimum wage, the immediate reaction from the Singapore families was to turn to other sources for cheaper maids, eg, from Indonesia and Sri Lanka, instead of employing Filipino maids.  In the end, it was their citizens who will suffer.

 

     Another example is that in the United States, the US government recently introduced the Age Discrimination Act.  The employers' reason is that, "If that is the case, then the best way is not to employ the older employees, so that they would not be accused of discrimination against them."  This is not going to the root of the problem.

     When there is a problem, we have to look squarely at the crux of problem.  We have to try and resolve it in a practical way, for example, the Job Recreation Scheme introduced by NTUC.  We have created 4,600 jobs in 2005.  This year, we plan to create another 10,000 jobs.  We want to tell our employers how to improve the welfare of our employees.  Now, we have more than 50 companies who have committed to participate in this scheme and to amend their human resource solution so that they can continue to employ the older workers beyond the statutory retirement age.  Through this pioneer project, we will be able to work out some solutions to motivate all the employers to do the same thing  by employing the older workers. 

     But, in the end, it is a question of mentality.  For example, in Japan, they have a new law which says that all employers should provide jobs for retired workers.  I think this is something that we could consider so that our employers will have no excuse not to employ the older workers.  Because they know that by employing the older workers, they would have some benefits derived therefrom. 

Column: 376

However, in the process of extending the retirement age, I think, most importantly, the Singapore Government, as the biggest employer in Singapore, should lead by example and see how we could let the older workers remain in their jobs, and work beyond their statutory retirement age.

 

     Generally speaking, this package should not be looked at purely as an ang pow.  In all the packages, we must let our people know of their existence and also the reason for their existence.  This package is not a welfare subsidy, as described by Mr Chiam See Tong. It is not just an incentive.  It serves to cheer up our workers too.  In the end, we hope that all workers, particularly the low-income workers, would take up the challenges and be self-reliant.

     However, on the details of the implementation, the Ministry of Finance needs to let the public know clearly the various bonus schemes.  To my surprise, even Prof. Ong Soh Khim and Mr Steve Chia did not really understand the working of this Growth Dividend. So long as you are an adult Singaporean, you will have a share, even though you are a housewife.  Even hon. Members of this House do not know this, so I am sure many Singaporeans would not know too.  There is a need for us to do some work, so that Singaporeans would understand the details of these schemes and the reason for this Progress Package.

 

     During my walkabout, some odd-job workers asked me whether declaring their income would cause adverse effects on their employers.  I think the Minister for Finance should clarify this doubt of our people.

Column: 377

declare my interest as a person from the private sector.

Member, Mr Steve Chia's call to abolish or lower taxes like licence fees and levies and, at the same time, advocating more and more give-aways and freebies.  Now, who will pay for all these?  Without sufficient taxes or revenue, such things cannot be sustained.  It is, in my mind, a recipe for disaster.  Does Mr Steve Chia know that Singapore will end up a bankrupt country?  This is not what we want.  It will be a sad day indeed if our Treasury becomes empty.

Column: 378

products that will give our economy the cutting edge.  It will be an engine for growth, and will bring Singapore to a higher level of economic development.

 

     My question is whether the Government has set up an apparatus to evaluate stringently the R&D proposals from companies, monitor their progress and performance and assess their results systematically.  Further, I wish to ask whether these companies, which benefit from the R&D grants, will be prepared to anchor themselves long term in Singapore.

Column: 379

     Unlike Mr Steve Chia who wants to cut most of the taxes, I will confine here to the discussion of one tax, and this is a tax not when we are alive but a tax when we are dead, ie, estate duty.  There is a common saying that, in life, we cannot escape taxes or death. But now, even after death, we cannot escape from the taxman.  The hope of many was dashed, at least for the time being, when estate duty was not abolished on Budget day.

 

     The Government says that it should reach a decision by the next Budget.  But the people are saying that we are waiting too long  -  tan jin ku.  May I ask why is the Government dragging its feet when Australia, New Zealand, Hong Kong, and even Malaysia, our next door neighbour, have abolished estate duty?  Singapore prides itself as being visionary and farsighted.  But now it seems we are lagging behind.

 

     I would like to ask the Government whether the abolition of estate duty in Hong Kong, for example, will make Hong Kong even more competitive than Singapore in attracting foreign talent, foreign investments and funds.  Further, why are we perpetuating a skewed limit of $9 million for residential properties and $600,000 limit for all other assets?  Would it not encourage disproportionate purchase of residential property?  If it is so skewed, why not simply do away with estate duty once and for all?

 

     Sir, the process of getting estate duty clearance upon the death of a relative is cumbersome, time consuming and tedious.  It takes months, and sometimes even years, to get clearance.  It is quite a hassle for the surviving relatives to search for records, bank statements and share transactions.  It is indeed difficult to seek clarification, as the deceased is no longer there to help clear enquiries.  It is very difficult for the families.  I, therefore, urge

Column: 380

Column: 420

first-time low-income home buyers, as presented in this Budget.  The schemes are designed to help and reward people in accordance with their age, income level, home size and even National Service.  It is also purposely slanted to share the wealth with the people in such a way that the poorest who live in the smallest flats and the oldest are the ones who get the most.  The high income earners, though getting the least from this particular package, are actually benefiting from the income tax reductions.  In short, the poor and the rich are both winners in this particular Budget, except that they are gaining their advantages through different means.

Column: 421

     Sir, years ago, people like to say "Government has money but the people do not."  It will sound more touching when it is said in Teochew.  With this kind of wealth-sharing package with the people, and if it can be done in a cyclical manner, the version would then be changed to: "The Government has money, but everyone has a share."

we would have a diverged opinion on this issue.  Yes, we do not have a very large reserve, compared with Japan or China, but we

Column: 422

are well above all the Asian countries, other than those mentioned. By reserve per capita, we are the highest in Asia.

    Sir, the next topic I would like to deal with is the $5 billion on R&D. We have moved away from the labour-intensive industry to that of the skilled and capital-intensive industry.  To continue and sustain the success in our economy, we must move up the value chain to that of the innovative and knowledge-based economy.  We shall then compete on knowledge and talent. We need original product design, research and development and creation of intellectual capital. 

 

     In the past five years, the Government funded a total of $12 billion in research and development.  It brought our research

Column: 423

spending, as a percentage of GDP, ahead of Holland, but it still falls behind countries like Korea, Japan, USA and Sweden.  The number of research scientists and engineers has grown to 87 per 10,000 in 2004.  This Budget happens to fall in the beginning year of the fourth Science and Technology Plan 2010.

 

     The funding in R&D for the next five years is significant in two aspects.  First, is the formation of the Research, Innovation and Enterprise Council, chaired by the Prime Minister.  It brings the R&D matter to the attention of the Cabinet level, a level higher than the previous Plan.  The fund committed for the next five years is not $5 billion, but $13.55 billion, which is more than the total allocation in the past 15 years.  During the past 15 years, it was only $12 billion. Column: 424

number compared with what the local universities could produce, bearing in mind also the postgraduate research post in our local universities is an area overwhelmingly dominated by the foreign students.  I could imagine the postgraduate research scientist and engineer posts created in the last five years, ie, in the third Science and Technology Plan, will be an area dominated by non-Singaporeans.  Initially, we have to start from scratch. Column: 425

if we would like our population benefit from the developments of the knowledge and innovative-based economy and let our population share the success of the economic growth.

     In development of the industrial capital, I am of the opinion that R&D work should be dominated by objective research, or what I would like to call it, product development.  This research should be an industrial-motivated work so that the outcome from the research will immediately interest the industry, either in the improvement of their existing products or leading to the emergence of new products.  In the committed research expenditure for the private and public sectors, I notice that the ratio was less than two. The ratio does not change much in the long-term projection given, whereas the leaders in the same field like Sweden, Japan and others, the ratio was in the order of three.  It means that our private sector research was lower in this ratio compared with other countries. 

 

Column: 426

    Though by the end of the fourth Science and Technology Plan, our research expenditure, as a percentage of GDP, would get closer to that of the world research leader, our actual private sector expenditure, as a percentage of GDP, would still be far behind those of the advanced knowledge-based economy. We shall not just, through the public sector research spending, keep up with the research spending percentage of GDP and catch up with the advanced knowledge-based countries. We should also actively promote private sector research in order not to lag behind the advanced knowledge-based economy.

 

    Sir, the next topic I would like to talk about is university fees which I initially have no intention to speak.   But, lately, SMU has announced another 5% rise in the school fees after the 15% increase - last year.  NUS and NTU also came up with the announcement of 3% increase. The Government would fund 75% of the courses and the students pay 25%.  If the universities increase their fees by 3%-5% per annum, and if it is agreeable and supported by the Ministry, I am inclined to believe that the Government must have agreed and committed to increase the Government funding per student by the same proportion. This is a good mechanism.  If it does happen, it locks together the students' fees, the Government's commitment and the university fee hike.  Every time, before the Government agrees with a fee increase by the universities, they must also, in the first place, give additional funding per student to the

Column: 427

universities.  Otherwise, if funding by the Government per student remains unchanged, an increase in the tuition fees implies the reduction of Government's commitment.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun (Hong Kah): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, Mr Steve Chia earlier accused the Government for concealing the truth by not including in the Budget proceeds from Government land sales, thereby showing a deficit budget.  I think either Mr Chia does not understand what constitutes reserves and the protection of it, or he is, indeed, deceiving the people himself.  Proceeds from Government land sales obviously is part of reserves, otherwise a rogue government, with the election promise to give away money, can come in easily and start to sell land and give the money to the people.  That is why we have the Presidential Election Act to protect the reserves, and land sales is part of the reserves.

 

     Sir, I have only two comments to make on the Budget.  The first is on R&D.  In his National Day Rally Speech last year, the Prime Minister spoke about the predicament our economy was in.  He likened it to being in between the two closing blades of a pair of scissors.  We are caught in between the lower cost of production in the liberalising economies of

Column: 428

China and India and the technological progress of developed nations.  If we cannot keep up with these technology advances, Singapore will become increasingly irrelevant, leading to a gradual fall in the standard of living, increasing unemployment and under-employment and eventually social discontent.  We certainly cannot afford for this to happen because it will lead to the end of Singapore as we know it. 

 

     Even our traditional forte of trade and commerce is not safe.  The Internet brings about increasing this intermediation whereby producers now find it more and more convenient and profitable to sell directly to consumers.  The music and movie industry is beginning to see this happen.  Many software sales are also now being sold by software authors directly to users, bypassing the distributors and publishers.  Super long-range commercial airliners may make Changi an airport of little consequence as they now can fly directly from European cities to Australia.  We live in times of change and, if we do not keep up, if we keep doing the same things in the same way, year after year, just because it had worked previously, and if we believe that if it ain't broken don't fix it, Singapore will be in big trouble.

 

     Creative destruction is the way to go in this age.  We must break down the old paradigms, systems and methods that worked before in order to progress and move forward.  If we do not do this, we will soon be competing with two billion other people from China and India because these people are hungry to be in the world league and are determined to catch up.  What then can Singapore do? 

 

     We took the first right steps in starting to focus on R&D in the 1980s.  This helped to change the mindset of our science and technology communities and that of our administrators and managers.  Singapore started to attract the high-tech

Column: 429

companies and gradually they began to start their research laboratories here and this, in turn, made our R&D more vibrant.  However, I hope we do not repeat the formula that was adopted in the past.  This is the formula of our past success in the last 30-plus years, but it is this very same formula that leads to our current weakness.  Singapore is overly dependent on the MNCs from the western countries.  We hardly have any home-grown companies that are globally significant and almost no large world-wide technology companies.  SIA and Creative Technology are notable exceptions, but how many more can we name?  Such giant corporations can become the driving force of successful economies.  If you look at the USA, many of these companies outsource their production to low wage countries like China and Latin-American nations, but the US economy remains strong due to the fact that the ownership and control of these companies remain in America. The R&D and productive design activities remain in the US and these are the high value added jobs which keep the value added to workers high.  Only then can there be increase in wages. 

 

     However, Sir, R&D alone is not enough.  In a Straits Times' article yesterday, featuring the start-up biotechnology company Veritas, the founder, Dr Rosemary Tan, was reported to lament that good R&D results were being wasted due to the lack of commercialisation efforts.  This is the reason why she started Veritas, which today has successfully produced and has started to sell an H5N1 bird flu test kit.  The company has also produced a malaria test kit, the technology obtained from an NUS laboratory where she worked as a PhD student.  If successful, Veritas would not only bring economic benefits to Singapore but it will benefit many throughout the world who may be saved from possible deaths.  Such companies have the capacity to make a positive difference in the world.  We must,

Column: 430

therefore, see to it that R&D leads to and spawns technology companies which may be capable of growing into significant world-class companies.  Singapore certainly needs such home-grown companies to keep her economy progressing with sustainable growth into the future. 

 

     Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I, therefore, strongly feel that special attention ought to be paid to the commercialisation of our research results.  It is from this commercialisation that we sow the seeds to grow giant technology companies.  R&D alone cannot achieve this.  While the Government has generously allocated over $13 billion for R&D, specific amounts for commercial exploitation of research results must be put aside.  Commercialisation is a process of transforming new technologies into commercially successful products.  The commercialisation process includes such efforts as market assessment, product design, manufacturing engineering, management of intellectual property rights, marketing strategy development, raising capital and workers' training.  This process is risky and can cost more than the R&D effort itself.  It is well known that our traditional businessmen and even the venture capital funds avoid taking such risks until more certainty is seen.  We also lack sufficient technology managers who have the expertise to exploit and defend our intellectual property rights.  This explains why many of our patents from our funded research institutes and research centres sit in dark steel cupboards waiting for the light of day. 

 

     Sir, after spending billions, how much are such patents in dark cupboards worth?  They are worth nothing.  Zero.  Unexploited patents will simply decay with time and technology progress of others.  When other competing technology hits the market first, it will be an uphill struggle to extract any value from the patents, even if you have a superior technology.

 

Column: 431

    Now, to be fair, the Singapore Government has tried to encourage technopreneurship with a variety of schemes.  However, none is focused on bridging the funding gap face by small firms seeking to commercialise technologies from universities and research institutes.  Although A*Star has introduced the Commercialisation of Technologies scheme (COT), COT only funds development activities of the research institutes under A*Star.  It does not fund the SMEs or technopreneurs trying to make use of and commercialise the research results of these institutes.  COT also does not cover universities and polytechnics.  EDB also recently introduced the Innovation Commercialisation Scheme (ICS) for small firms.  ICS reimburses up to 50% of the qualifying cost of supported project, up to a maximum of $75,000.  This limited amount that is available and the restrictive terms of reimbursement may not help solve the financial needs of many small start-ups seeking to commercialise R&D, especially those from the biotechnology sector.

 

     Sir, let me share a few facts from the most technologically advanced country, and that is the USA.  In 1980, the US passed the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act.  It is mandated that federal funded laboratories spend at least 0.5% of their budgets on technology transfer. This was followed by the Small Business Innovation Act of 1982, also known as the Bayh-Dole Act.  The Act established the Small Business Innovation and Research Scheme (SBIR).  Subsequent amendments to date compel that at least 2.5% of extramural research budget from federal funded programmes be spent on commercialisation of research with the small businesses.

 

     In his letter to the Straits Times published on 5th September 2005, a reader Lim Keng Hwee wrote, SBIR has

Column: 432

served the US economy well by bringing the private and public sectors and academia together.  This model may help to do the same for Singapore.  Sir, I agree with him.  In an advanced country such as the USA, where risk capital is supposed to be readily available, the Government continues to provide financial resources and grants to help small businesses exploit new technologies.  A notable success from this SBIR programme is Qualcomm.  I am sure Members would have heard of Qualcomm.  The company is the key player behind the CDMA mobile phone technology and is today worth about US$80 billion.  Should Singapore not emulate such success? 

 

     While on the topic of R&D, I would like to commend the Government on starting to focus on three key sectors, ie, biomedical sciences, interactive and digital media and the environment and water technologies.  These are relevant to Singapore's economy and the products and services from these industries are exportable world-wide.  However, I would like to suggest that we also look at research into energy, renewable and efficient energy resources, energy storage, efficient energy distribution as well as efficient energy use.  The recent spike in oil prices reminds us that energy is a very valuable resource which can be scarce.  Singapore imports all her energy needs and the savings, when such research bears fruits, will be significant.  More important, the know-how can also be exported internationally, bringing significant revenues.

 

     Sir, for the R&D, in summary, I would like to recommend that the Government study and incorporate a significant funding scheme to help with the exploitation and commercialisation of technology.  Such a scheme, I hope, will in time help spawn many technology start-ups, a few of which will grow into significant global technology companies, generating billions of dollars for the future

Column: 433

Singapore economy and bringing high value employment to our people.  Further, I would like to suggest that energy research be added as a new field for the NRF pursuit. 

 

     Sir, I come to the second point, which is the Progress Package.  Earlier, I have said that for Singapore to stay relevant and compete successfully in the global market we have no choice but to move up the technological ladder through R&D and its commercialisation.  However, such progress would also mean that the rich-poor divide in our society will get wider.  The rich-poor gap will be worse if we fail to solve our structural unemployment or under-employment problem and cannot help the lower 20% of our people find work or upgrade.  In this regard, I must praise the Government for thinking long and hard on how to spend the surpluses it has accumulated during its term of Government with the people.  It differentiates the PAP from the Opposition parties.  It is easy to give away money, but it is hard to give it meaningfully so that it will reap long term benefits for the country and the people.

 

     Sir, the Progress Package can be divided into three main categories, namely, the Growth Dividends, help for the needy, and the Workfare Bonus.  I have spoken on the concept of negative income tax in FY 2003 budget debate and the need to use some form of negative income tax to encourage people to work.  I am, therefore, pleased to see that the Government has accepted the Workfare principle and is giving out Workfare Bonus this year.  However, the Government has not committed to giving Workfare Bonus every year for fear that it would be entrenched and loses its effectiveness.  There is also a fear the employers may take advantage of it and depress wages.  Sir, if Workfare Bonus is to be given once in four to five years, I am not sure whether it will work either.  We need to come up with a regular mechanism where

Column: 434

older and lower income workers can benefit without the pitfalls of a crutch mentality.  I think, in this regard, the Government has not spent enough time or thought to look into what other mechanisms that we can have. 

 

     In the older days, when the Government was concerned about food prices, NTUC Fairprice was set up as a cooperative with the social objective to stabilise prices.  Can we now consider the setting up of a labour cooperative, also with a social objective and supported by the Government, to train and place workers for jobs? 

I believe Government funding for such a cooperative would be a more meaningful approach of Workfare.  Sir, I hope the Government would look into my suggestion and see how we can have the Workfare principle implemented on a more regular basis, so that workers can be encouraged to work and, at the same time, benefit from some form of negative income tax.

 

     With that, Sir, I support the Budget.

Contingency fund

Column: 436

the Prime Minister and Finance Minister has cautioned that there are downside risks, chief among which is an outbreak of the Avian flu. Meetings, International Conferences and Exhibitions (MICE)
